last_replies.name: Anonymous

>>620800661
You either start with 0 and go in story order, playing Kiwamis instead originals or you start with 1 on PS2 and go in release order if you want /v/ cred.

last_replies.name: Moose
last_replies.com:
>>620800661
Either start in release order with 1 by emulating it and then follow that order or start with 0 and go in numbered order with the Kiwamis replacing 1 and 2 since they're expecting you to have played 0 (K2 even spoils Majima's ending). Starting in release order is a bit harder to get into because obviously it's an older game and they didn't have everything ironed out but it's still fine even today once you get used to some of the quirks and you will see how everything progressed in terms of gameplay, writing, mechanics, etc. Starting with 0 gives you a strong intro game but you jump all over the place in gameplay, writing, engines, mechanics, and so on, and it gives you different expectations like styles (Only in spinoffs outside of 0 and K1), characters (Majima doesn't even act like 0's until 4's flashbacks as one simple example), writing (Substories took until around Kenzan to start having more comedy than 1 and 2 and they don't stop scam substories being a majority of them until after 3), and more.

If you end up liking the series then give 1 and 2 a go if you played K1 and K2 or vice-versa. They are not 1:1 remakes and you did not experience the same game. You mainly just experienced most of the same main story and substories.

>>620801201
>otherwise Kiwami > 0
You don't do this. Kiwami is a sequel to 0, it's not a 1:1 remake of 1. It expects you to have played 0 going into it and has Majima and multiple substories reference it all the time. You also don't go from 1 to 0, you go in release order if you start with 1 because 0 builds off of all the games prior to its release since it's an anniversary game.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>620801148
My dad's an engineer who helps with hiring, and has described the company's hiring process for his department to me. There's a minimum of 3 interviews with 3 separate people. If all 3 of those people like you they invite you to the company to be given a tour and interview with at least 2 more people. Then, if you're not vetoed by either of those people, you're asked to give a presentation, which will be seen by the entire department. The entire department then convenes for a round table discussion on if to hire you. If everyone agrees, the VP of the department talks to the CEO about it and he makes a final decision. The whole thing tends to take about a month.
In fairness, he's in an advanced field and they're unusually picky. However, he himself got the job with just 2 interviews, one with the CEO, because the boss knew him from a previous job. The takeaway: networking is more important than anything else you can possibly do in your career.

>>620779729
Unironically WoW becoming shit kicked my addiction to it. Jumped on the FFXIV train but was never as glued to it or any other MMO even when they were as good or better. Quit entirely off MMOs period mostly by just replacing it with other addictions and realizing that almost anything else was a better use of time. Smoked a shitload of weed, jerked off too much, and played a bunch of single-player RPGs, then got bored of smoking weed and jerking off all the time.

Whenever I felt the pull to dive back into MMOs, I'd open up the Shadowlands cinematics or look at pictures of dracthyr and remind myself that any MMO that goes on too long can turn into this shitheap, then I'd open up my old discord server and see the same nolifes queueing up for the same shit that they'd been doing for the better part of a decade or more with nothing in their actual life to show for it. They were just stuck in a loop but pissing their short lives away doing it. After that I'd hop off the computer to go solder or practice guitar because at least those things had tangible rewards for working on them.
If I'm being totally honest though, a big part of it was also probably that I had a big hard-on for Warcraft lore, and watching it turn into a dumpster fire probably helped shock me out of one of the biggest draws to the setting for me and kicking off my abandonment of the genre, so my experience is somewhat biased.

>>620797771
Well there's generally two ways to go about doing things to deliver impact in combat.

1. Hitstop. 2D fighters like Street Fighter and King of Fighters use this a lot to great effect.
2. No hitstop but very context-sensitive and immediate pain reactions. 3D fighters like Tekken and Soul Calibur do this to great effect. Hitting someone's shins creates a different animation than hitting someone's head.

Forspoken does neither. There's no hitstop and there's no perceptible pain reaction animations or flinches when the crocodiles in OP's webm are getting slashed.
